description: The level-set function \( S_D(\tilde{x}, \tilde{y}, \tilde{z}) \) defines the Schwarz \( D \) minimal surface, a triply periodic minimal surface (TPMS) commonly used to model bicontinuous structures in materials science and crystallography. Here, \( \tilde{x} \), \( \tilde{y} \), and \( \tilde{z} \) denote dimensionless spatial coordinates, typically scaled by the lattice period. The surface itself is represented implicitly as the zero-level set where \( S_D = 0 \). The function is composed of a sum of four trigonometric terms, each a product of sines and cosines of the scaled coordinates, reflecting the cubic symmetry and periodicity of the surface. This formulation provides an efficient implicit representation for identifying surface points and analyzing the topology of the \( D \)-surface.

Equation (2) defines the implicit surface function \( S_P(\tilde{x}, \tilde{y}, \tilde{z}) \) for the Schwarz \( P \) minimal surface. Here, \( \tilde{x}, \tilde{y}, \tilde{z} \) denote reduced Cartesian coordinates, which are scaled spatial variables defined as \( \tilde{x} = x \cdot m\pi / l_x \), \( \tilde{y} = y \cdot n\pi / l_y \), and \( \tilde{z} = z \cdot p\pi / l_z \), where \( x, y, z \) are the original coordinates, and \( m, n, p \) represent the number of fundamental cell units of the surface along the \( X \), \( Y \), and \( Z \) lattice directions within an orthogonal simulation box of dimensions \( l_x, l_y, l_z \). The equation \( \cos 2\tilde{x} + \cos 2\tilde{y} + \cos 2\tilde{z} = 0 \) describes the locus of points in space that satisfy the condition for the triply periodic minimal surface, thereby generating the characteristic infinite, connected pore structure of the Schwarz \( P \) surface.

The equation defines the reduced coordinate \(\tilde{x}\) for an atom within a periodic structure. Here, \(x\) denotes the atom's original Cartesian coordinate along the \(X\)-axis, \(l_x\) is the length of the orthogonal simulation box along that same direction, and \(m\) is the number of fundamental unit cells of the surface structure replicated along the \(X\)-axis. The transformation scales the physical coordinate \(x\) by the factor \(m\pi / l_x\), effectively normalizing it by the box length and converting it into a dimensionless reduced coordinate that is proportional to the phase or wave number used in the trigonometric functions describing the periodic minimal surface. This mapping is part of a set of similar transformations for all spatial dimensions, facilitating the mathematical representation of atomic positions relative to the underlying crystallographic lattice.

The equation defines the reduced coordinate \(\tilde{y}\) for an atom within a periodic structure. Here, \(y\) denotes the atom's actual Cartesian coordinate along the \(Y\)-axis, \(n\) represents the number of fundamental unit cells along this direction within the simulation box, and \(l_y\) is the corresponding box length. The transformation scales the physical coordinate by the factor \(n\pi / l_y\), effectively normalizing it by the box dimension and mapping it onto a dimensionless domain proportional to \(\pi\). This scaling is part of a set of coordinate transformations applied to facilitate the mathematical description of atomic positions within the periodic supercell of a Schwarz minimal surface structure.

The equation defines the reduced coordinate \(\tilde{z}\) for an atom within a periodic structure. Here, \(z\) denotes the atom's original Cartesian coordinate along the \(Z\)-axis, \(p\) represents the number of fundamental cell units along this same (001) lattice direction, and \(l_y\) is the box length along the \(Y\)-axis. The relationship scales the physical coordinate \(z\) by the dimensionless factor \(p\pi / l_y\), transforming it into a reduced, dimensionless coordinate \(\tilde{z}\). This specific scaling, which uses the box length from an orthogonal direction (\(l_y\)), is part of a consistent set of transformations applied to all Cartesian coordinates to normalize them with respect to the system's periodicity and unit cell replication.

Equation (3) expresses the Young-Laplace law as applied to a grain boundary (GB) within a crystalline solid. Here, \( P \) denotes the capillary pressure acting across the boundary, \( \gamma_{GB} \) represents the specific energy of the grain boundary, and \( R \) is the mean radius of curvature of the boundary. The relationship describes how the pressure difference is directly proportional to the boundary energy and inversely proportional to its curvature, such that a vanishing curvature results in a minimal capillary pressure.

Equation (4) quantifies the additional pressure, \(S\), that arises at a grain boundary (GB) due to an applied shear stress, \(\tau\), acting on neighboring crystalline lattices. Here, \(E_A\) and \(E_B\) denote the Young's moduli of the adjacent grains \(A\) and \(B\), respectively. The relationship shows that \(S\) is proportional to the square of the applied stress and depends on the difference in the mechanical compliance (\(1/E\)) of the two grains. Since the intrinsic anisotropy of crystals typically ensures \(E_A \neq E_B\), this equation captures a persistent thermodynamic driving force for GB motion, stemming from the differential elastic strain energy stored in the two lattices under stress.

Equation (5) defines the condition for the thermal instability of a supercrystal (SC) under applied stress. Here, \( T_S \) denotes the temperature at which this instability occurs. The total pressure acting on the system, \( p(T_S) \), is expressed as the sum of two temperature-dependent components: \( P(T_S) \), which represents the externally applied mechanical pressure, and \( S(T_S) \), which signifies an intrinsic stress contribution, likely arising from structural or interfacial effects within the material. The equation states that instability ensues when this total pressure equals a critical threshold, \( P_c \), which is identified as the critical pressure required for grain boundary migration. Thus, the equation provides a criterion for predicting the onset of microstructural rearrangement by relating the temperature-dependent stress state to a material-specific critical value.

Equation (6) describes the asymptotic behavior of the time-averaged structural order parameter, \(\langle S(T) \rangle\), as a function of temperature \(T\). Here, \(S\) denotes a local structural order parameter quantifying the degree of crystalline order, and the angle brackets \(\langle \cdot \rangle\) represent an ensemble or time average. The relation \(\langle S(T) \rangle \rightarrow 0\) signifies that the average crystalline order vanishes in the limit as the temperature approaches the grain boundary melting point, \(T_m^{\mathrm{GB}}\). This mathematical statement captures the physical condition that, up to this melting temperature, the grain boundary maintains a minimal pressure state where thermal fluctuations do not restore crystalline order, leading to a complete loss of structural coherence at \(T_m^{\mathrm{GB}}\).

Equation (7) expresses the minimal pressure condition that holds along the grain boundary (GB) melting line up to the melting point \( T_m^{\mathrm{GB}} \). Here, \( p(T) \) denotes the total effective pressure acting on the GB, which is decomposed into a static component \( P(T) \) and a thermally averaged stress contribution \( \langle S(T) \rangle \). The condition \( p(T) \rightarrow 0 \) signifies that the net pressure vanishes, ensuring mechanical equilibrium at the GB irrespective of thermal fluctuations and any critical pressure \( P_c \). This relationship thus defines the thermodynamic state where the GB is stabilized against melting under a balance of internal stresses.

The equation \( E_A = E_B \) expresses a condition of mechanical equilibrium under zero external pressure. Here, \( E_A \) and \( E_B \) denote the energies of two distinct structural domains or phases, labeled A and B, respectively. The equality signifies that these energies are balanced, implying no net thermodynamic driving force for transformation or migration between the domains. In the context of grain boundary systems, this condition is associated with a minimal mean driving force for boundary motion, which is characteristic of certain stable microstructural configurations.

The equation \(D _ { S } = 3 ~ \mathrm { n m }\) defines a critical size threshold for structural stability in a system of dissociated supercells (D-SCs). Here, \(D _ { S }\) denotes the aperture size or characteristic diameter of a D-SC. The relationship specifies that when \(D _ { S }\) reaches or exceeds this value of 3 nanometers, grain boundary (GB) migration is completely suppressed, and the structure achieves maximum thermal stability, even at temperatures approaching the material's melting point. This condition represents a stability limit; for D-SCs with smaller aperture sizes, thermal destabilization occurs at significantly lower temperatures due to mechanisms such as coherent twin boundary (CTB) or GB annihilation.
